text: Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes? Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: It could be a cancer spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or it could be that you bled into your adrenal gland, and so, uh, hemorrhaged into the adrenal gland. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. text: Healthcare Professional: - after that spot. It’s… Or are you worried that it will drop the PSA and not necessarily correlate the scans? Doctor: Uh if the PSA drops it means the cancer is done. text: Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It’s alright. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
